articles.headline: As Germany Booms, It Faces a Shortage of Workers
articles.snippet: An aging population and inflation-fighting measures that have kept wages low are making it difficult for companies to find workers.
articles.abstract: An aging population and inflation-fighting measures that have kept wages low are making it difficult for companies to find workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  Dana Russow longs for the day when she will not have to worry about staffing problems.

articles.headline: Germany and France Roll Out Plan to Boost Euro
articles.snippet: The move prompted immediate opposition but could create an embryonic economic government for Europe.
articles.abstract: The move prompted immediate opposition but could create an embryonic economic government for Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Initiating a bold effort to strengthen the euro, Germany and France on Friday laid down far-reaching plans to deepen integration among the 17 nations that use the currency. The move prompted immediate opposition, but could lead to embryonic economic government for Europe.

articles.headline: Bank of America to Create Troubled Loans Unit
articles.snippet: Most of the 1.3 million troubled loans were picked up when the bank bought Countrywide Financial in 2008.
articles.abstract: Most of the 1.3 million troubled loans were picked up when the bank bought Countrywide Financial in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America said Friday that it would create a unit to handle 1.3 million soured mortgages as Brian T. Moynihan, the bank’s chief executive, tried to distance the company from the fallout of the mortgage crisis.

articles.headline: The Gamble of Lending Peer to Peer
articles.snippet: Using the Web sites Prosper and Lending Club, individual investors can lend money at decent interest rates to other individuals. But it’s hardly risk-free.
articles.abstract: Using the Web sites Prosper and Lending Club, individual investors can lend money at decent interest rates to other individuals. But it’s hardly risk-free.
articles.lead_paragraph: When peer-to-peer online lending first became possible in the United States five years ago, using the Web to make money by lending it to fellow citizens in need seemed wonderfully subversive.

articles.headline: Raw Milk Cheesemakers Fret Over Possible New Rules
articles.snippet: As the government reconsiders a 60-day aging rule for raw milk cheeses, artisanal producers fear that their businesses will suffer.
articles.abstract: As the government reconsiders a 60-day aging rule for raw milk cheeses, artisanal producers fear that their businesses will suffer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are considering whether to tighten food safety rules for cheese made with unpasteurized milk  and the possibility has cheesemakers and foodies worried that the result will be cheese that is less tasty and not much safer.

articles.headline: It May Be a Sputnik Moment, but Science Fairs Are Lagging
articles.snippet: Participation in high school science fairs appears to be declining, and many teachers blame the administration’s own policy.
articles.abstract: Participation in high school science fairs appears to be declining, and many teachers blame the administration’s own policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rarely have school science fairs, a source of pride and panic for generations of American students, achieved such prominence on the national stage. President Obama held one at the White House last fall. And last week he said that America should celebrate its science fair winners like Sunday’s Super Bowl champions, or risk losing the nation’s competitive edge.

articles.headline: In a Graying Population, Business Opportunity
articles.snippet: Researchers are helping companies make products geared toward older people yet attractive to younger buyers.
articles.abstract: Researchers are helping companies make products geared toward older people yet attractive to younger buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

articles.headline: West Backs Gradual Egyptian Transition
articles.snippet: The United States and European nations supported attempts by Egypt’s vice president to broker a compromise that wouldn’t immediately remove President Hosni Mubarak.
articles.abstract: The United States and European nations supported attempts by Egypt’s vice president to broker a compromise that wouldn’t immediately remove President Hosni Mubarak.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Kareem Fahim, Mark Landler and Anthony Shadid.

articles.headline: Preapproved: Well, It Sounded Good
articles.snippet: A would-be buyer received preapproval for a mortgage from her homebuilder’s banking unit. But the loan was later denied, and she’s now out the $20,000 deposit.
articles.abstract: A would-be buyer received preapproval for a mortgage from her homebuilder’s banking unit. But the loan was later denied, and she’s now out the $20,000 deposit.
articles.lead_paragraph: MELISSA CALDERONE was ready for a fresh start when she made plans last year to move to Florida from New Jersey. Recently remarried, she signed a contract in mid-March on a house to be built in Windermere, Fla., by Pulte Homes, the nation’s largest homebuilder. The neighborhood had good schools for her three children and two stepchildren. It was also close to where Ms. Calderone’s parents lived.

articles.headline: Egypt Stability Hinges on a Divided Military
articles.snippet: American officials say Egypt’s military holds the key to the governing of Egypt and the country’s future.
articles.abstract: American officials say Egypt’s military holds the key to the governing of Egypt and the country’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A classified cable sent to Washington from the United States Embassy in Cairo in 2008 reported that a disgruntled midlevel Egyptian officer corps referred to the country’s powerful defense minister, Field Marshal Mohamed Tantawi, as “Mubarak’s poodle”  incompetent and archaic but intensely loyal to his now-besieged president.

articles.headline: Who’s the Boss, You or Your Gadget?
articles.snippet: As more workers find it hard to go without their devices, the border between the office and home may be destroyed.
articles.abstract: As more workers find it hard to go without their devices, the border between the office and home may be destroyed.
articles.lead_paragraph: GIVEN the widespread adoption of smartphones, text messaging, video calling and social media, today’s professionals mean it when they brag about staying connected to work 24/7.

articles.headline: States Struggle to Disarm People Who’ve Lost Right to Own Guns
articles.snippet: There is serious vulnerability when it comes to keeping guns out of the hands of the mentally unstable and others.
articles.abstract: There is serious vulnerability when it comes to keeping guns out of the hands of the mentally unstable and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: By law, Roy Perez should not have had a gun three years ago when he shot his mother 16 times in their home in Baldwin Park, Calif., killing her, and then went next door and killed a woman and her 4-year-old daughter.
articles.byline: By Ed Connolly and Michael Luo

articles.headline: After First Talks, Egypt Opposition Vows New Protest
articles.snippet: The government portrayed itself as on the way to negotiating an end to the uprising. Protesters dismissed the claim, but it was better received in Washington.
articles.abstract: The government portrayed itself as on the way to negotiating an end to the uprising. Protesters dismissed the claim, but it was better received in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Leaders of the Egyptian democracy movement vowed Sunday to escalate their pressure for the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak, even as his government portrayed itself as already in the midst of American-approved negotiations to end the uprising, now in its 13th day.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: A Crisis of Faith in Britain’s Central Banker
articles.snippet: Mervyn King has been condemned for the economy, but it is worse for him that his boldest proposal is being ignored.
articles.abstract: Mervyn King has been condemned for the economy, but it is worse for him that his boldest proposal is being ignored.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  A central banker need not be loved, but at the least he should command respect  and in Britain these days Mervyn King cannot count on either.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Al Jazeera Hopes Reports From Egypt Open Doors in U.S.
articles.snippet: Al Jazeera hopes its English-language coverage of protests in Egypt and Tunisia will help it gain access to an American cable television audience.
articles.abstract: Al Jazeera hopes its English-language coverage of protests in Egypt and Tunisia will help it gain access to an American cable television audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar  “Our bureau in Cairo has been attacked.”

articles.headline: The Answers Are Out There, and New Q. and A. Sites Dig Them Up
articles.snippet: WikiAnswers and Yahoo Answers are the granddaddies, but a new tide of similar sites is rising.
articles.abstract: WikiAnswers and Yahoo Answers are the granddaddies, but a new tide of similar sites is rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Internet circles, the hunt is always on for the next big thing. But lately an older idea is enjoying a renaissance: sites where users ask and answer questions. A flurry of start-ups in this field are gathering speed and attracting the eyes and wallets of venture capitalists.

articles.headline: Disney Looking Into Cradle for Customers
articles.snippet: Disney Baby seeks to introduce mothers and newborns to products while they are in the hospital.
articles.abstract: Disney Baby seeks to introduce mothers and newborns to products while they are in the hospital.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company has started an ambitious and risky march toward the one corner of childhood it does not already dominate: newborns.

articles.headline: EBay Says Big Growth Is Not Over
articles.snippet: EBay’s chief executive said the company can now “go on the offensive” after years of losing market share.
articles.abstract: EBay’s chief executive said the company can now “go on the offensive” after years of losing market share.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  EBay was growing so fast early in its history that Meg Whitman, its former chief executive, liked to joke that “a monkey could drive this train.”

articles.headline: Egypt’s Ire Turns to Confidant of Mubarak’s Son
articles.snippet: Ahmed Ezz, a steel tycoon and party insider, has represented the intersection of money, politics and power in Egypt. His world has come undone.
articles.abstract: Ahmed Ezz, a steel tycoon and party insider, has represented the intersection of money, politics and power in Egypt. His world has come undone.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As Egyptians turned their anger on symbols of the state late last month, torching police stations along with the headquarters of President Hosni Mubarak’s ruling party, they reserved a special hatred for a garish building with black tinted windows in an upscale neighborhood, setting fire to it three times.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim, Michael Slackman and David Rohde

articles.headline: Ridiculed, an N.F.L. Owner Goes to Court
articles.snippet: An article in November in the Washington City Paper ridiculed Daniel M. Snyder, the owner of the Redskins, and his response was to bring in the lawyers.
articles.abstract: An article in November in the Washington City Paper ridiculed Daniel M. Snyder, the owner of the Redskins, and his response was to bring in the lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in November, when Daniel M. Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, was pilloried at length in a piece in the Washington City Paper, a local weekly, he had a number of options: He could have ignored the article, contacted the newspaper and asked for equal time or corrections, or he could have used his bully pulpit as the owner of both a pro sports team and a number of local radio stations to respond.

articles.headline: Super Bowl Ads Mine Decades of Americana
articles.snippet: The Super Bowl ads dished up a dizzying mélange of star turns, movie references, homages to television shows, snippets of songs and even hat-tips to other spots.
articles.abstract: The Super Bowl ads dished up a dizzying mélange of star turns, movie references, homages to television shows, snippets of songs and even hat-tips to other spots.
articles.lead_paragraph: The advertising bowl that took place inside Super Bowl XLV on Sunday offered a wild — and somewhat welcome — ride through six decades of popular culture.

articles.headline: In Eastern Afghanistan, at War With the Taliban’s Shadowy Rule
articles.snippet: A picture is emerging of an underground government in Ghazni Province by Taliban fighters who have established the rudiments of a civilian administration to complement their shadowy combat force.
articles.abstract: A picture is emerging of an underground government in Ghazni Province by Taliban fighters who have established the rudiments of a civilian administration to complement their shadowy combat force.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE ANDAR, Afghanistan  Midway through December, Afghan police officers arrested a man who had hidden a fake bomb near a government office in Miri, a village in eastern Afghanistan. The man, who gave the name Muhammad Mir, confessed, saying he wanted to gauge the security force’s reactions to a Taliban attack, according to American intelligence officials.

articles.headline: Betting on News, AOL Is Buying The Huffington Post
articles.snippet: The deal would give AOL a major presence in journalism, demonstrating the company’s intention to rely more heavily on online advertising.
articles.abstract: The deal would give AOL a major presence in journalism, demonstrating the company’s intention to rely more heavily on online advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Huffington Post, which began in 2005 with a meager $1 million investment and has grown into one of the most heavily visited news Web sites in the country, is being acquired by AOL in a deal that creates an unlikely pairing of two online media giants.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: Egypt’s Leaders Seek to Project Air of Normalcy
articles.snippet: A traffic jam formed as stores and banks were staffed, but in Tahrir Square, a smaller crowd continued the revolt.
articles.abstract: A traffic jam formed as stores and banks were staffed, but in Tahrir Square, a smaller crowd continued the revolt.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  As Egypt’s revolt entered its third week the government of President Hosni Mubarak sought to seize the initiative from protesters still crowding Tahrir Square on Monday, offering a pay raise for government employees, announcing a date for opening the stock market and projecting an air of normalcy in a city reeling just days ago.
